Knowledge Point: Some speakers have reported an alternative 3\textsc{du} pronominal form /ndin/. However, it is not well attested in my corpus. The only examples of it seem to reflect an adnominal \isi{demonstrative} rather than a \isi{personal pronoun}. I suspect that it is an abridged form of the \isi{dual} \isi{distal} \isi{demonstrative} andin (cf. the form [nda] for the \isi{singular} \isi{distal} \isi{demonstrative} anda, \sectref{sec:7.3}). The form [ndin], for example, occurs at the end of an NP in \REF{ex:pron:1}.
Content 1: \gsrc Kambok inom ngusuwa \textbf{ndin} asika ndule. | \gll Kambok inom ngusuwa \textbf{ndin} asi-ka ndï=ula-e | \gls Kambuku mother poor 3DU? sit-let 3PL=weave-IPFV | \glt `Two poor women from Kambuku [village] used to sit and weave them.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:pron:2}, the functional similarity between [a]ndin ‘\textsc{du.dist}’ (‘those two’) and anda ‘\textsc{sg.dist}’ (‘that’) is clear, as each form immediately follows a corresponding \isi{numeral}.
Content 1: \gsrc wik wopa kwa nda nini \textbf{ndintïna} | \gll wik wopa kwa anda nini \textbf{ndin}=tï-na | \gls week all one SG.DIST two 3DU?=take-IRR | \glt `for all of one week, or two’

Knowledge Point: Possessive forms may refer to first \isi{person} \REF{ex:pron:3}, second \isi{person} \REF{ex:pron:4}, or third \isi{person} \REF{ex:pron:5} \isi{possessor}s.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Nïnji} anapa mï atalap. | \gll \textbf{nï-nji} anapa mï atal-a-p | \gls 1SG-POSS sister 3SG.SUBJ laughter-break-PFV | \glt `My sister laughed.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Unji} aweta mï anma. | \gll \textbf{u-nji} aweta mï anma | \gls 2SG-POSS friend 3SG.SUBJ good | \glt `Your friend is nice.’
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{Manji} wonmi ndï namlip. | \gll \textbf{ma-nji} wonmi ndï namli=p | \gls 3SG.OBJ-POSS hair 3PL soft=COP | \glt `Her hair is soft.’

Knowledge Point: \isi{Possessor}s may be \isi{singular}, \isi{dual}, or \isi{plural}, and may occur in object roles as well as subject roles. In example \REF{ex:pron:6}, the possessive form refers to a third \isi{person} \isi{plural} \isi{possessor}, here part of a \isi{direct object} NP.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï lïmndï \textbf{ndïnji} aweta mala. | \gll ndï lïmndï \textbf{ndï-nji} aweta ma=ala | \gls 3PL eye 3PL-POSS friend 3SG.OBJ=see | \glt `They saw their friend.’

Knowledge Point: Third \isi{person} possessive forms, such as the one in \REF{ex:pron:7}, can have ambiguous reference, pointing either (reflexively) to an \isi{antecedent} in the clause or to a third party not necessarily mentioned in the clause.
Content 1: \gsrc Ginam mï inim mo \textbf{manji} aweta ndït atalp. | \gll Ginam\textsubscript{i} mï inim ma=u \textbf{ma-nji}\textsubscript{i/j} aweta ndï=tï ata-lï-p | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ water 3SG.OBJ=from 3SG.OBJ-POSS friend 3PL=take up-put-PFV | \glt `Ginam pulled her friends out of the water.’

Knowledge Point: That is, manji ‘\textsc{3sg.obj-poss}’ in sentence \REF{ex:pron:7} can refer either to Ginam’s friends or to someone else’s (e.g., Yawat’s). To clarify that the \isi{pronoun} refers to Ginam, a different form may instead be used, composed of the \isi{reflexive} \isi{pronoun} of the appropriate \isi{number} (\sectref{sec:6.3}) and \textit{{}-nji} ‘\textsc{poss}’, giving the meaning ‘X’s own’, as in \REF{ex:pron:8}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ginam mï inim mo \textbf{manji} aweta ndït atalp. | \gll Ginam\textsubscript{i} mï inim ma=u \textbf{ma-nji}\textsubscript{i/j} aweta ndï=tï ata-lï-p | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ water 3SG.OBJ=from 3SG.OBJ-POSS friend 3PL=take up-put-PFV | \glt `Ginam pulled her friends out of the water.’
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: These forms are similar in function to certain pronouns found in some other languages, such as the \ili{Latin} possessive \isi{reflexive} \isi{pronoun} suus ‘his/her/its/their own’. In addition to their use in clarifying third \isi{person} \isi{antecedent}s, however, the Ulwa forms may also be used with first or second \isi{person} reference in order to convey the sense ‘my own’, ‘our own’, ‘your own’, and so on, as in \REF{ex:pron:9}, \REF{ex:pron:10}, and \REF{ex:pron:11}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï lïmndï \textbf{ambïnji} aweta mala. | \gll nï lïmndï \textbf{ambï-nji} aweta ma=ala | \gls 1SG eye SG.REFL-POSS friend 3SG.OBJ=see | \glt `I saw my own friend.’
Content 2: \gsrc Min lïmndï \textbf{ambinji} aweta mala. | \gll min lïmndï \textbf{ambin-nji} aweta ma=ala | \gls 3DU eye DU.REFL-POSS friend 3SG.OBJ=see | \glt `The two of them saw their own friend.’
Content 3: \gsrc Un lïmndï \textbf{amblanji} aweta ndala. | \gll un lïmndï \textbf{ambla-nji} aweta ndï=ala | \gls 2PL eye PL.REFL-POSS friend 3SG.OBJ=see | \glt `You saw your own friends.’

Knowledge Point: It may here be noted that possessive forms need not necessarily precede nouns. Although they cannot precede verbs (without the verbs having been \isi{nominalize}d), they can precede \isi{adjective}s. This happens, however, only when the \isi{adjective} is functioning substantively (i.e., nominally) (\sectref{sec:5.3}), as in \REF{ex:pron:12} and \REF{ex:pron:13}. This further suggests that there is little if any \isi{morphosyntactic} distinction between property words (i.e., “\isi{adjective}s”) and \isi{semantic}ally more prototypical nouns.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Manji} anma ndï apa map. | \gll \textbf{ma-nji} anma ndï apa ma=p | \gls 3SG.OBJ-POSS good 3PL house 3SG.OBJ=be | \glt `His good ones [= daughters] are in the house.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Nïnji} njukuta mï wandam i. | \gll \textbf{nï-nji} njukuta mï wandam i | \gls 1SG-POSS small 3SG.SUBJ jungle go.PFV | \glt `My small one [= dog] went into the jungle.’

Knowledge Point: Finally, the possessive forms can be used substantively with an implied noun, as in \REF{ex:pron:14} and \REF{ex:pron:15}.
Content 1: \gsrc Unji apa mï njukutap \textbf{nïnji} mï ambip. | \gll u-nji apa mï njukuta=p \textbf{nï-nji} mï ambi=p | \gls 2SG-POSS house 3SG.SUBJ small=COP 1SG-POSS 3SG.SUBJ big=COP | \glt ‘Your house is small; mine is big.’
Content 2: \gsrc Kayta manji tïn mï \textbf{nïnji} asap. | \gll Kayta ma-nji tïn mï \textbf{nï-nji} asa-p | \gls [name] 3SG.OBJ-POSS dog 3SG.SUBJ 1SG-POSS hit-PFV | \glt `Kayta’s dog attacked mine.’

Knowledge Point: Thus, these pronouns are similar to their \ili{English} translations ending in ‘-self’ or ‘-selves’, in that there is no distinction made among them for \isi{person} -- whether first, second, or third -- but they are distinguished for \isi{number}. These three forms are based on the same root, /amb(ï)-/. The use of \isi{reflexive} pronouns is illustrated by examples \REF{ex:pron:16} through \REF{ex:pron:22}.
Content 1: \gsrc Tambana mï \textbf{ambuwalinda}. | \gll Tambana mï \textbf{ambï}=wali-nda | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ SG.REFL=hit-IRR | \glt `Tambana will hit herself.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ay ndïnkap ndïn \textbf{amblan} up. | \gll ay ndï=nïkï-p ndï=n \textbf{ambla}=n u-p | \gls sago 3PL=dig-PFV 3PL=OBL PL.REFL=OBL put-PFV | \glt `[They] made [packets of] sago and left them for themselves.’

Knowledge Point: There are indications that the \is{binding} \isi{binding domain} for \isi{anaphor}s (i.e., \isi{reflexive} pronouns) in Ulwa may be something greater than the clause -- that is, unlike in \ili{English}, it is possible for the \isi{antecedent} of a \isi{reflexive} \isi{pronoun} in Ulwa to be located in a so-called higher clause. All known examples of this occur when the \isi{matrix clause} (containing the \isi{antecedent}) introduces the \isi{embedded clause} (containing the \isi{reflexive} \isi{pronoun}) by means of a verb of speaking (or thinking).\footnote{Thus, Ulwa may be said to exhibit a sort \isi{logophoricity}, since these \isi{reflexive}s must be bound by an \isi{antecedent} whose \isi{speech} (or thought) is being reported. It should be noted, however, that there is no special \isi{logophoric pronoun} in Ulwa.} Examples \REF{ex:pron:23} and \REF{ex:pron:24} illustrate the use of \isi{reflexive} pronouns with \isi{antecedent}s in a “higher” clause.
Content 1: \gsrc Wangasa Wore ngala ini tï \textbf{ambïnanda} nate. | \gll Wangasa\textsubscript{i} Wore ngala ini tï \textbf{ambï}\textsubscript{i}=na-nda na-ta-e | \gls [name] [place] PL.PROX ground take SG.REFL=give-IRR DETR-say-DEP | \glt `Wangasa says that these Wore [people] will give him land.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Ambïwalinda} \textbf{ambul} undate nakap. | \gll \textbf{ambï}=wali-nda \textbf{ambï}=ul unda-t-e na-kï-p | \gls SG.REFL=hit-IRR SG.REFL=with go{-spec-dep} DETR-say-PFV | \glt `[He] thought that [the crocodile] might go around with him to kill him.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:pron:25} illustrates this long-distance \is{logophoricity} (or logophoric) \isi{anaphoric reference} with a \isi{reflexive} pronominal modifier, here used as a bare \isi{possessor}, without the form \textit{{}-nji} ‘\textsc{poss}’ (\sectref{sec:6.2}).
Content 1: \gsrc Kwa mï man \textbf{ambaweta} kap. | \gll kwa mï\textsubscript{i} ma=n \textbf{ambï}\textsubscript{i}=aweta kï-p | \gls one 3SG.SUBJ 3SG.OBJ=OBL SG.REFL=friend say-PFV | \glt `Someone said that it was his friend.’

Knowledge Point: Also to be mentioned here is an interesting \isi{idiom}atic use of the \isi{reflexive} pronominal \isi{object marker} ambla= ‘\textsc{pl.refl}’. When used with the verb asa- {\textasciitilde} wali- ‘hit, kill’, this marker does not necessarily have a \isi{reflexive} (or reciprocal) sense, but rather gives the entire verb the \isi{intransitive} meaning ‘fight’ (as in battle). The object of fighting (the enemy) can be marked in a \isi{postpositional phrase} with the \isi{postposition} ul ‘with’. This can cause ambiguity not unlike what often occurs in \ili{English}, since this same \isi{postpositional phrase} can mark either enemies or allies.\footnote{Cf. \ili{English} sentences such as The English fought with the French.} Sentences \REF{ex:pron:26}, \REF{ex:pron:27}, and \REF{ex:pron:28} exemplify this use of the verb asa- {\textasciitilde} wali- ‘hit, kill’ with the \isi{reflexive} pronominal \isi{object marker} ambla= ‘\textsc{pl.refl}’.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndiya lop ndiya wa lop ndul \textbf{amblasap}. | \gll ndï=iya lo-p ndï=iya wa lo-p ndï=ul \textbf{ambla}=asa-p | \gls 3PL=toward go-PFV 3PL=toward village go-PFV 3PL=with PL.REFL=hit-PFV | \glt `[They] went to them, went to them in the village, and fought with them [as enemies].’
Content 2: \gsrc Unan ndiya ma ndul \textbf{amblawalinda}! | \gll unan ndï=iya ma ndï=ul \textbf{ambla}=wali-nda | \gls 1PL.INCL 3PL=toward go 3PL=with PL.REFL=hit-IRR | \glt `Let’s go to them and fight with them [as allies]!’
Content 3: \gsrc Ndul ndul \textbf{amblasap}. | \gll ndï=ul ndï=ul \textbf{ambla}=asa-p | \gls 3PL=with 3PL=with PL.REFL=hit-PFV | \glt `With them [= our allies] we fought with them [= our enemies].’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{dual} and \isi{plural} \isi{reflexive} pronouns may, alternatively, convey a reciprocal sense (i.e., ‘each other’, ‘one another’). There may thus arise ambiguity in meaning, typically clarified through context. For example, sentence \REF{ex:pron:19} could be interpreted either as having a \isi{reflexive} sense or as having a reciprocal sense (i.e., either ‘you two know each other’ or ‘you two know yourselves’). Examples of reciprocal meaning are given in sentences \REF{ex:pron:29} through \REF{ex:pron:34}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ngun \textbf{ambinkalamp}. | \gll ngun \textbf{ambin}=kalam=p | \gls 2DU DU.REFL=knowledge=COP | \glt `You two know yourselves.’
Content 2: \gsrc Kolpe Womel min \textbf{ambinasap}. | \gll Kolpe Womel min \textbf{ambin}=asa-p | \gls [name] [name] 3DU DU.REFL=hit-PFV | \glt `Kolpe and Womel fought each other.’
Content 3: \gsrc An ambi nape an lïmndï \textbf{amblala}. | \gll an ambi na-p-e an lïmndï \textbf{ambla}=ala | \gls 1PL.EXCL big DETR-be{-dep} 1PL.EXCL eye PL.REFL=see | \glt `When we had gotten big, we looked at one another.’

Knowledge Point: Sometimes a \isi{personal pronoun} occurs where a \isi{reflexive}/\isi{reciprocal} \isi{pronoun} may otherwise be expected. It is unclear whether this is a permissible variation in \isi{pronoun} use or an indication of \isi{grammatical attrition}. It is common with the verb ala- ‘see’, as in \REF{ex:pron:35} and \REF{ex:pron:36}.
Content 1: \gsrc An lïmndï \textbf{anala}. | \gll an lïmndï \textbf{an}=ala | \gls 1PL.EXCL eye 1PL.EXCL=see | \glt `We saw ourselves.’
Content 2: \gsrc Olsem nï lïmndï \textbf{nala}. | \gll olsem nï lïmndï \textbf{nï}=ala | \gls thus 1SG eye 1SG=see | \glt `I see myself like this.’

Knowledge Point: \isi{Indefinite} referents can be denoted by the \isi{numeral}/\isi{interrogative word} kwa ‘one; who?; someone’ when the referent is a human or by the \isi{phrase} nji kwa ‘one thing, something’ when the referent is non-human, as illustrated by examples \REF{ex:pron:37} through \REF{ex:pron:40}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Kwa} nip. | \gll \textbf{kwa} ni-p | \gls one die-PFV | \glt (a) ‘Someone died.’\\’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï lïmndï \textbf{nji kwa} ala | \gll nï lïmndï \textbf{nji} \textbf{kwa} ala | \gls 1SG eye thing one see | \glt `I saw something.’

Knowledge Point: Sentence \REF{ex:pron:37}, if given the right \isi{intonation}, could be interpreted as a \isi{question}, as suggested by the second translation given. This is because the form [kwa] is also used as an \isi{interrogative pronoun} meaning ‘who?’ (\sectref{sec:6.5}).
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Kwa} nip. | \gll \textbf{kwa} ni-p | \gls one die-PFV | \glt (a) ‘Someone died.’\\’

Knowledge Point: \isi{Dual} and \isi{plural} forms do not tend to be used for \isi{indefinite} pronominal referents, at least not on their own. For non-\isi{singular} \isi{indefinite} referents, however, the word kuma ‘some’ may follow an NP, whether human \REF{ex:pron:41} or non-human \REF{ex:pron:42}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ankam \textbf{kuma} mbin. | \gll ankam \textbf{kuma} mbï-i-n | \gls person some here-come-PFV | \glt `Some people came.’
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: It is possible for \isi{subject marker}s (\sectref{sec:7.1}) to follow kuma ‘some’ \REF{ex:pron:43}. Although \isi{subject marker}s may also follow kwa ‘someone’, this is less common. In this way, kwa ‘someone’ seems to pattern with what are more likely true pronouns, whereas kuma ‘some’ seems to pattern more with \isi{adjective}s.
Content 1: \gsrc Ya \textbf{kuma ndï} liyu. | \gll ya \textbf{kuma} \textbf{ndï} li-u | \gls coconut some 3PL down-put | \glt `Some coconuts fell.’

Knowledge Point: It should be noted as well that \isi{object marker}s (\sectref{sec:7.2}) can follow object NPs ending with kuma ‘some’, as in \REF{ex:pron:44} and \REF{ex:pron:45}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï lïmndï ankam \textbf{kuma ndala}. | \gll nï lïmndï ankam \textbf{kuma} \textbf{ndï=}ala | \gls 1SG eye person some 3PL=see | \glt `I saw some people.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï ya \textbf{kuma} \textbf{ndamap}. | \gll nï ya \textbf{kuma} \textbf{ndï=}ama-p | \gls 1SG coconut some 3PL=eat-PFV | \glt `I ate some coconuts.’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{interrogative} form angos ‘what?’ can also be used in \isi{negative}-\isi{polarity} sentences (e.g., with the \isi{negator} ango ‘\textsc{neg}’) to mean something along the lines of ‘whatever, whatsoever, anything’, as in examples \REF{ex:pron:46} through \REF{ex:pron:49}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ango \textbf{angos} na iye. | \gll ango \textbf{angos} na i-e | \gls NEG what talk go.PFV-DEP | \glt ‘[They] came to no thought whatsoever.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï ango \textbf{angos} ame. | \gll nï ango \textbf{angos} ama-e | \gls 1SG NEG what eat-IPFV | \glt `I’m not eating anything.’

Knowledge Point: When combined with nji ‘thing’, angos ‘what?’ can convey the sense ‘whatever’ in \isi{positive}-\isi{polarity} sentences \REF{ex:pron:50}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Angos nji} inata una lïmndï mandï ande. | \gll \textbf{angos} \textbf{nji} i-na-ta unan lïmndï ma=andï ande | \gls what thing come-IRR-COND 1PL.INCL eye 3SG=see ok | \glt `Whatever may come, we would see it [and say:] “OK”.’

Knowledge Point: The forms of the \isi{indefinite pronoun}s kwa ‘one, someone’ and kuma ‘some’ (\sectref{sec:6.4}) are the same as the forms used in asking \isi{content question}s in Ulwa. The \isi{pronoun} kwa ‘one, someone’ thus also means ‘who?’ (for a \isi{singular} human referent), as illustrated by example \REF{ex:pron:51}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Kwa} (mï) lamndu ndasap? | \gll \textbf{kwa} (mï) lamndu ndï=asa-p | \gls one (3SG.SUBJ) pig 3PL=hit-PFV | \glt `Who killed the pigs?’

Knowledge Point: multiple human referents, as in \REF{ex:pron:52} and \REF{ex:pron:53}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Kuma} (min) lamndu ndasap? | \gll \textbf{kuma} (min) lamndu ndï=asa-p | \gls some (3DU) pig 3PL=hit-PFV | \glt `Who [= which (two) people] killed the pigs?’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Kuma} (ndï) lamndu ndasap? | \gll \textbf{kuma} (ndï) lamndu ndï=asa-p | \gls some (3DU) pig 3PL=hit-PFV | \glt `Who [= which (three or more) people] killed the pigs?’

Knowledge Point: For non-human referents, the \isi{question word} angos ‘what?’ is used, as in \REF{ex:pron:54}, \REF{ex:pron:55}, and \REF{ex:pron:56}. For all \isi{interrogative} pronouns, \isi{subject marker}s are optional (as are \isi{object marker}s).
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Angos} (mï) lamndu ndasap? | \gll \textbf{angos} (mï) lamndu ndï=asa-p | \gls what (3SG.SUBJ) pig 3PL=hit-PFV | \glt `What killed the pigs?’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Angos} (min) lamndu ndasap? | \gll \textbf{angos} (min) lamndu ndï=asa-p | \gls what (3DU) pig 3PL=hit-PFV | \glt `What [= which (two) things] killed the pigs?’
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{Angos} (ndï) lamndu ndasap? | \gll \textbf{angos} (ndï) lamndu ndï=asa-p | \gls what (3PL) pig 3PL=hit-PFV | \glt `What [= which (three or more) things] killed the pigs?’

Knowledge Point: In \isi{content question}s (i.e., wh- questions), the wh- word remains \isi{in situ}; it is not preposed to the front of the clause as in \ili{English}. Accordingly, when the ‘who’ or ‘what’ being asked about is not the grammatical subject, but rather the object of a verb, then the \isi{interrogative} \isi{pronoun} occurs in the typical object position (i.e., immediately before the verb), as in examples \REF{ex:pron:57} through \REF{ex:pron:60}.
Content 1: \gsrc U lïmndï \textbf{kwa} mala? | \gll u lïmndï \textbf{kwa} ma=ala | \gls 2SG eye one 3SG.OBJ=see | \glt `Whom did you see?’
Content 2: \gsrc Nungol mï \textbf{angos} minanglalop? | \gll nungol mï \textbf{angos} min=angla-lo-p | \gls child 3SG.SUBJ what 3DU=await-go-PFV | \glt `What [= which two things] did the boy look for?’

Knowledge Point: When preceding an NP, the \isi{interrogative word} ango ‘which?’ (compare angos ‘what?’) conveys the sense ‘which [NP]?’. There is no distinction made based on \isi{animacy} or \isi{number} or \isi{grammatical relation} (i.e., whether the questioned element is a subject or an object). Significantly, whereas modifiers of NPs such as \isi{adjective}s or \isi{determiner}s follow their associated NPs (\sectref{sec:9.1}), the modifying element ango ‘which?’ precedes its NP. This could serve the functional means of differentiating between ‘which [NP]?’ and ‘[NP] \textsc{neg}’.\footnote{Cf. \textbf{ango tïn} mamap ‘which dog ate it?’ vs. \textbf{tïn ango} mamap ‘the dog did not eat it’.} Sentences \REF{ex:pron:61} through \REF{ex:pron:64} illustrate the use of ango ‘which?’.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Ango tïn} (mï) mïnda mamap? | \gll \textbf{ango} \textbf{tïn} (mï) mïnda ma=ama-p | \gls which dog (3SG.SUBJ) banana 3SG.OBJ=eat-PFV | \glt `Which dog ate the banana?’
Content 2: \gsrc U \textbf{ango} apa nditap? | \gll u \textbf{ango} apa ndï=ita-p | \gls 2SG which house 3PL=build-PFV | \glt `Which houses did you build?’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{interrogative} \isi{pronoun} ‘whose?’ takes the form kwanji ‘whose [\textsc{sg]}’ for \isi{singular} \isi{possessor}s and kumanji ‘whose [\textsc{nsg]}’ for \isi{dual} or \isi{plural} \isi{possessor}s (no distinction is made here between the two), as may be seen in examples \REF{ex:pron:65}, \REF{ex:pron:66}, and \REF{ex:pron:67}. These forms are transparently derived from the words kwa ‘one’ or kuma ‘some’ plus nji ‘thing’ (cf. \isi{possessive pronoun}s, \sectref{sec:6.2}).
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Kwanji} nungol (mï) nïnji yot tïn? | \gll \textbf{kwa-nji} nungol (mï) nï-nji yot tï-n | \gls one-POSS child (3SG.SUBJ) 1SG-POSS machete take-PFV | \glt `Whose child took my machete?’
Content 2: \gsrc Anda \textbf{kwanji} mana? | \gll anda \textbf{kwa-nji} mana | \gls SG.DIST one{-poss} spear | \glt `Whose spear is that?’
Content 3: \gsrc U \textbf{kumanji} apa maytap? | \gll u \textbf{kuma-nji} apa ma=ita-p | \gls 2SG some{-poss} house 3SG.OBJ=build-PFV | \glt `Whose [plural] house did you build?’

Knowledge Point: Sentences \REF{ex:pron:68}, \REF{ex:pron:70}, and \REF{ex:pron:71} illustrate the use of basic \isi{intensive pronoun}s to place emphasis on a subject.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Nawa} lamndu masap. | \gll \textbf{nï-awa} lamndu ma=asa-p | \gls 1SG-INT pig 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `I myself killed the pig.’
Content 2: \gsrc Kayta \textbf{mawa} lamndu masap. | \gll Kayta \textbf{ma-awa} lamndu ma=asa-p | \gls [name] 3SG.OBJ-INT pig 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `Kayta himself killed the pig.’
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{Wawa} utam nduwanap. | \gll \textbf{u-awa} utam ndï=wana-p | \gls 2SG-INT yam 3PL=cook-PFV | \glt `You yourself cooked the yams.’

Knowledge Point: Sentences \REF{ex:pron:72}, \REF{ex:pron:74}, and \REF{ex:pron:75} illustrate the use of \isi{partitive-intensive pronoun}s to emphasize sole participation of a referent (or group of referents).
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Nuwe} lamndu masap. | \gll \textbf{nï-we} lamndu ma=asa-p | \gls 1SG-PART.INT pig 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `I myself [in the group] killed the pig.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Nduwe} i. | \gll \textbf{ndï-we} i | \gls 3PL-PART.INT go.PFV | \glt `They themselves [out of a group] went.’
Content 3: \gsrc Kolpe Kongos \textbf{ambinwe} lamndu ndasape nakap. | \gll Kolpe Kongos \textbf{ambin-we} lamndu ndï=asa-p-e na-kï-p | \gls [name] [name] DU.REFL-PART.INT pig 3PL=hit-PFV-DEP DETR-say-PFV | \glt `Kolpe and Kongos said that they themselves [out of a group] killed the pigs.’

Knowledge Point: Although both paradigms of \isi{intensive pronoun}s are written as sets of single lexemes, the composite morphemes of each putative word are quite clear and can, at times, occur separately, as in examples \REF{ex:pron:76}, \REF{ex:pron:77}, and \REF{ex:pron:78}, each of which contains both the \is{partitive-intensive pronoun} partitive-intensive pronominal form (of the 3\textsc{pl} \isi{pronoun}) and the basic \isi{intensive} form (as a separate morpheme, without any \isi{person} or \isi{number} marking).
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Nduwe awa} nïmal ngayte mo liyen. | \gll \textbf{ndï-we} \textbf{awa} nïmal nga=ita-e ma=u li-i-en | \gls 3PL-PART.INT INT river SG.PROX=build-IPFV 3SG.OBJ=from down-go.PFV-NMLZ | \glt `They themselves alone were the ones who built [along] this river, having come down along it.’
Content 2: \gsrc Manji nji ngala \textbf{nduwe awa}. | \gll ma-nji nji ngala \textbf{ndï-we} \textbf{awa} | \gls 3SG.OBJ-POSS thing PL.PROX 3PL-PART.INT INT | \glt `These things are his.’
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{Nduwe awa} man ne. | \gll \textbf{ndï-we} \textbf{awa} ma=n ni-e | \gls 3PL-PART.INT INT 3SG.OBJ=OBL act-IPFV | \glt `They themselves do it.’

Knowledge Point: It is also possible for the form we ‘alone’ to occur as a separate morpheme, \isi{phonological}ly distinct from the preceding word (even if that word is a \isi{pronoun}), as in \REF{ex:pron:79} and \REF{ex:pron:80}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mangusuwa \textbf{we} i. | \gll ma-ngusuwa \textbf{we} i | \gls 3SG.OBJ{-}poor alone go.PFV | \glt `The poor thing went alone.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï \textbf{we} alum ngol mbïka lowonda. | \gll nï \textbf{we} alum nga=ul mbï-ka lo-wo-nda | \gls 1SG alone child SG.PROX=with here-thus IRR-sleep-IRR | \glt `I alone will sleep here with this child.’

Knowledge Point: In addition to these \isi{intensive} pronominal forms, there is a set of what are here called \isi{emphatic} pronominal forms. While there may also exist a full paradigm for such forms in all \isi{person}s and \isi{number}s, both for \isi{personal pronoun}s and for \isi{demonstrative}s (see \sectref{sec:7.3}), only four forms are attested in texts \REF{ex:pron:80a}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Notably, these forms are based on the subject (and not object) forms of the pronouns (e.g., /mï-nam/ and not \textsuperscript{†}/ma-nam/). They all appear to contain the \isi{emphatic} \isi{suffix} -nam ‘\textsc{emph}’. The form [ngam] seems to have undergone a \isi{phonological} reduction, assuming that it derives from nga ‘\textsc{sg.prox}’ (‘this’) plus -nam ‘\textsc{emph’}. The \isi{emphatic} pronominal forms are illustrated by examples \REF{ex:pron:81} through \REF{ex:pron:84}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Mïnam} amun masal Dumngul nungol ngawatawe. | \gll mï-\textbf{nam} amun ma=si-al Dumngul nungol nga=wat-aw-e | \gls 3SG.SUBJ-EMPH now 3SG.OBJ=push-PFV [name] child SG.PROX=atop-put.IPFV-DEP | \glt `Now he’s the one -- [they] call Dumngul’s son after him.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Ngam} u nïn lïmndï ngaka nase. | \gll nga-\textbf{nam} u nï=n lïmndï nga=ka nï=asa-e | \gls SG.PROX-EMPH 2SG 1SG=OBL eye SG.PROX=in 1SG=hit-DEP | \glt `This is it -- you shot me in my eye.’

Knowledge Point: These topic-marking forms can be used to contrast one referent from another or to introduce a new referent after, say, a pause in the discourse. Some of their functions are illustrated by sentences \REF{ex:pron:85} through \REF{ex:pron:90}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Ngunanambi} ango lïmndï manji pamili ndale. | \gll \textbf{ngunan-ambi} ango lïmndï ma-nji pamili ndï=ala-e | \gls 1DU.INCL-TOP NEG eye 3SG.OBJ-POSS family 3PL=see-DEP | \glt `As for us, we don’t see his family.’
Content 2: \gsrc Tarambi \textbf{mambi} anmbï mbïpe. | \gll Tarambi \textbf{ma-ambi} an-mbï mbï-p-e | \gls [name] 3SG.OBJ-TOP out-here here-be{-ipfv} | \glt `As for Tarambi, he stays outside.’

Knowledge Point: The topic-marking pronominal forms are found almost exclusively in subject NPs. However, they appear as \isi{object-marker}s \isi{proclitic}s as part of \isi{irrealis} or \isi{imperative} expressions with the verb ka- ‘let, leave, allow’, thereby creating the \isi{idiom}atic meaning ‘forget (about) it/forget (about) them!’. This use is illustrated in examples \REF{ex:pron:91} through \REF{ex:pron:94}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Mambilakan} nï nakamp. | \gll \textbf{ma-ambi}=la-ka-n nï na-kamb-p | \gls 3SG.OBJ-TOP=IRR-let-IMP 1SG DETR-shun-PFV | \glt `Forget it; I’ve had enough.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Mambilakana}! | \gll \textbf{ma-ambi}=la-ka-na | \gls 3SG.OBJ-TOP=IRR-let-IRR | \glt `Shocking!’

Knowledge Point: As an \isi{adjective}, ngusuwa ‘poor’ has the same distribution to be expected of any \is{attributive adjective} (attributive) \isi{adjective} in Ulwa (\sectref{sec:5.1}): it follows the nominal \isi{head} of the NP and may precede a \isi{determiner}. Its use as an \isi{adjective} is illustrated by sentences \REF{ex:pron:95} through \REF{ex:pron:99}.
Content 1: \gsrc Yawa \textbf{ngusuwa} nda ma unap mat iyap. | \gll yawa \textbf{ngusuwa} anda ma u=nap ma=tï i-ap | \gls uncle poor SG.DIST go 2SG=for 3SG.OBJ=take go.PFV-PFV | \glt `That poor uncle went and brought it for you.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ngunanji itom \textbf{ngusuwa} minwe ya ndïn awe. | \gll ngunan-nji itom \textbf{ngusuwa} min-we ya ndï=n aw-e | \gls 1DU.INCL-POSS father poor 3DU-PART.INT coconut 3PL=OBL put{-ipfv} | \glt `Only our two poor fathers used to plant coconuts.’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{adjective} seen in examples \REF{ex:pron:95} through \REF{ex:pron:99} may be contrasted with the pronominal forms, which never precede \isi{subject marker}s, \isi{object marker}s, or any other \isi{determiner}s belonging to the same \isi{phrase}. The pronominal forms are also capable of being expanded with the ending [-ta], which is never seen in the \isi{adjective} ngusuwa ‘poor’. Sentences \REF{ex:pron:100} through \REF{ex:pron:107} illustrate the use of these affective pronouns.
Content 1: \gsrc Yawa \textbf{ngusuwa} nda ma unap mat iyap. | \gll yawa \textbf{ngusuwa} anda ma u=nap ma=tï i-ap | \gls uncle poor SG.DIST go 2SG=for 3SG.OBJ=take go.PFV-PFV | \glt `That poor uncle went and brought it for you.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ngunanji itom \textbf{ngusuwa} minwe ya ndïn awe. | \gll ngunan-nji itom \textbf{ngusuwa} min-we ya ndï=n aw-e | \gls 1DU.INCL-POSS father poor 3DU-PART.INT coconut 3PL=OBL put{-ipfv} | \glt `Only our two poor fathers used to plant coconuts.’
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{Mangusuwa} ya ndïn num up. | \gll \textbf{ma-ngusuwa} ya ndï=n num u-p | \gls 3SG.OBJ-poor coconut 3PL=OBL canoe put-PFV | \glt `The poor thing put coconuts in the canoe.’
Content 4: \gsrc \textbf{Ndïngusuwata} mbïpe matane wapen. | \gll \textbf{ndï-ngusuwata} mbï-p-e ma=ta-n-e wap-en | \gls 3PL-poor here-be{-dep} 3SG.OBJ=say-IPFV-DEP be.PST-NMLZ | \glt `When the poor things were here, [they] used to talk about it.’
